Those risks include among others matters we have noted in our latest earnings release and filings with the SEC. Harley-Davidson disclaims any obligation to update information in this call. This morning our President and CEO, Matt Levatich; and CFO, John Olin will be hosting. So Matt let's get started.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Amy and thank you, everyone, for joining us on the call today. We talked in depth about our Q2 results and what we see going forward. You've all read the news release we issued this morning, Jon and I will bring context and perspective to those re
componenttext:
Thanks, Amy and thank you, everyone, for joining us on the call today. We talked in depth about our Q2 results and what we see going forward. You've all read the news release we issued this morning, Jon and I will bring context and perspective to those results and highlight some of the factors that are and you can get the best read on our outlook for Q3, the full year and beyond. Before John goes into the details financials, I would like to comment on 2 things. Market performance and then company performance. From a market perspective, we're very pleased with the share performance in the US where we gained 2 points share in the heavyweight segment for the quarter on top of our already strong share position. As the U.S. remains highly competitive, this gain is an important validation that our initial investments to drive demand are working. Since the beginning of the year, we made investments designed to impact customer choice and support our long-term strategy of growing our reach and impact with customers and strong returns to investors. Our demand driving investments are focused in 4 areas: increasing product and brand awareness, growing new ridership in The United States, increasing and enhancing brand access and accelerating the cadence and impact of new products.
Our teams across the globe launched several initiatives behind these investments with precision and effectiveness delivering solid results in our international markets and driving the market share gains in The United States. Looking internationally, our retail sales were up 4.3%, driven by continued growth in Asia, Canada and Mexico and our best ever quarter for Harley-Davidson in our EMEA region. Our investments to increase demo rides in EMEA, for example, was a major contributor to our growth in the region in Q2, nothing seems to be a better for a new customers that experiencing one of our great bikes firsthand.
In Asia, we maintained our #1 share in Australia, India and Japan. We focused on [indiscernible] growing ridership. And in the U.S., the Live Your Legend campaign and other demand investments build significant allowance and helped drive a 30% increase in demo rides so far this year and a 40% increase in the number of students trained through the Harley Davidson Riding Academy. There are also some real positives in the nature of retail sales and market share gains that further reinforce the strength of our work both near and long-term. Notably, we're very pleased to have growth year-to-date in the all-important young adult segment in United States. The young adult segment is not only important for the long-term, it is the most competitive market segment in the U.S. All of these initiatives combined represent an important long-term play as we seek to grow the sport in U.S. and bring new customers into the brand in all of our markets. I'm encouraged that the actions that we've taken so far this year have been enabled us to make progress and our long-term growth strategy, However, worldwide sales for the quarter were down due to significant declines in the US industry. We expected the industry to be down in the first of the year as we lapped industry growth in 2015 that was stimulated by the shift in currency and the resulting competitive discounting, and as we also expected by continued weakness in the oil-dependent areas. We did not, however, expect the industry as a whole would be as soft as it is. While our share gains helped to blunt the full impact of this weak market, lackluster industry sales have had a significant impact on our results and our forward expectations. As a result, we're taking the prudent step to lower expected 2016 shipments. This is largely due to what we believe will be continued pressure on the industry growth in the U.S., coupled with caution as we consider the potential impact of the macro economic uncertainty on sales globally. We remain steadfast in our commitment to keep supply in line with the demand to protect the premium [indiscernible] and we believe the steps we're taking will ensure dealer inventory is in line by year-end to support the expected sales environment. All in, we now plan to ship fewer motorcycles for the full year, and are revising our shipment guidance from 1% to 3% growth to approximately down 1% to up 1% from 2015. Our production plans and shipment expectations are intended to drive flat inventory at year-end, even with an expanded model range. These actions will have a drag on our earnings for the full year. So we're revising our full year expected operating margin down 1 percentage point to 15% to 16%. Without question, we must assure inventory balance for our long-term competitiveness and profitability for both the company and our incredible dealers.
Now, shifting from market to company performance. You'll see that gross margin declined in the quarter. There are number of factors here that both John and I will address. As we've discussed on prior calls, we expected higher manufacturing costs due to the significant investments we're making to advance our flexible manufacturing strategy. These investments are complex and require discipline, planning and execution, including numerous down days, inventory bridges and careful ramp plans. The net impact can be seen in changes to gross margin, shipments and inventory patterns in the second quarter and the impact will continue in Q3 as we ramp back to full production. The investments are part of the manufacturing flexible really strategy that will enhance cost-effectiveness flexibility now our Kansas City plant.
Another factor in gross margin performance in Q2 is the impact of volume and mix adjustments we made to capture the demand lift from the Cruiser success we experienced in the quarter while also adjusting downward the total volume in the softer-than-expected U.S. industry. The U.S. industry turned swiftly in the second quarter. We responded with discipline and commitment in an effort to keep supply in line with demand and these actions also impacted our gross margin in the quarter. While difficult, these actions were necessary to set us up for success for our model year launch and also for 2017 and beyond. And speaking of new products and our new model launch, I'm incredibly excited about our lineup which  we will unveil to our global dealer network at the end of August. We'll add to the stable of products driving our current success and we've got some incredible products in the pipeline for 2018, our 115th anniversary and beyond. Before I turn it over to John, I will take this opportunity to thank everyone associated with this great company, employees, dealers, suppliers and our passionate riders. I'm proud of our team and all the work that is being done at Harley-Davidson. We're in challenging times.  Political and cultural forces are all working against confidence and security for people everywhere in the world. Everyone in our company is aware and attuned to what we need to do. We have 113-year history of challenges we stood up to and faced down. The power of personal freedom for our riders is stronger than ever take and we all aim to deliver for them. We understand the intense need to manage through these challenges effectively and deliver results. We're stewards this incredible brand and of your investment and we do not take that responsibility lightly. Without question, driving demand, growing the business and delivering strong returns are top priorities for all of us at Harley-Davidson and we're focused every day on delivering for our riders near-term and long-term in order to do so.
With that, I'm going to turn it over to John. Thank you,

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning to everyone. Today I will provide additional insight around our second quarter financial results found in our press release and supporting [indiscernible]  Starting on Slide 9. During the quarter, revenue was $1.86 million.
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning to everyone. Today I will provide additional insight around our second quarter financial results found in our press release and supporting [indiscernible]  Starting on Slide 9. During the quarter, revenue was $1.86 million. Net income was $280.4 million. Diluted earnings per share were $1.55. Operating income from the Motorcycles segment was down 15.2% from last year s second quarter. Segment revenue was up 1.2% in the quarter behind a 3.5% increase in Motorcycles shipments. Gross margin as a percentage of revenue decreased versus prior year as a result of unfavorable product mix and currency exchange in addition to higher year-over-year manufacturing cost. SG&A was also up in the quarter as we increased our demand driving and product development investments. Operating income as a percent of revenue in Q2 was 19.3%. At HDFS, operating income was up 9.4% year-over-year in part driven by a gain related to a full securitization. The quarter also reflected a higher corporate interests expense resulting to from our 2015 recapitalization and [indiscernible] for more effective tax rate. Despite the challenging conditions we continue to face, we remain focused on driving demand and delivering strong margins and strong returns over the long-term.
On Slide 10, you will see worldwide retail sales of new Harley-Davidson Motorcycles in Q2 were down 1.9% versus prior year. International retail sales were up year-over-year, while the U.S. retail sales were lower-than-expected on surprisingly weak industry results. Despite the ongoing challenging macroeconomic and motorcycle industry conditions, we were encouraged with our share gains in the second quarter. Our ability to grow internationally and partially offset the industry headwinds in The United States, reinforces our intensified focus on driving demand and enhancing our strong brand.
Our increased investments and driving demand and product development through positive market share results in the U.S. and in Europe during the first half of this year. In addition, the positive response to our new 2016 motorcycle models continued during the second quarter. As Matt noted, we continue to be committed and steadfast in our resolve to manage supply in line with demand. Given the port U.S. industry retail sales in Q2 and softness expected into the second half of 2016, we're taking steps to adjust retail inventory in the U.S. and now expect year-end retail inventory in the U.S. to be in line with prior year versus our previous expectation to grow year-end retail inventory. Considering our desire to reduce year-end U.S. retail inventory in the face of soft U.S. industry sales and the uncertainty resulting from global macroeconomic challenges, we have lowered our full year shipment expectations. Let's take a closer look at the U.S on Slide 11. Q2 retail sales in the U.S. were down 5.2% versus prior year behind weak U.S. industry sales. The impact of the weak U.S. industry on our sales was partially offset by strong gains in market share. The U.S. industry was down 8.6% during the quarter.  While we expected the industry to be down in the first half of 2016, we do not expect the extent to, which the second quarter declined, especially considering the high level of competitive discounting that continued during the quarter. We believe the industry was down due to the following 2 factors: lapping strong year-ago industry growth driven by the onset of aggressive competitive discounting in the year-ago period and weak sales in oil-dependent areas.
While the industry lagged our expectations, we're encouraged both our Q2 market share of 49.5% in the U.S., which was up a strong to 2.0 percentage point. We believe our second quarter market share gains were driven by our demand driving investments focused on growing product awareness and growing ridership in the U.S. and a strong reception to our new 2016 motorcycle models. While our competitors continue to engage in levels of discounting similar to the first quarter, and at more aggressive levels than in last year's second quarter, we were very pleased that we were able to increase market share in the U.S. and enhancing actions. U.S. retail inventory was up at the end of the second quarter driven by 3 factors: First, we offered 5 incremental models versus the prior year; second, inventory was up as we shipped all model year 2016 Motorcycles in advance of the Q3 ERP implementation; and, also as a result of lower-than-expected Q2 retail sales.
On Slide 12, you'll see retail sales in our international markets were up in Q2. All regions were up except Latin America, which was impacted by weakness in Brazil. Excluding Brazil, international markets were up 5.6%. During the quarter, EMEA retail sales were up 8.2% behind a great reception to our new 2016 motorcycle models and increased demand driving investments. This quarter strong retail sales also benefited from lapping prior year retail sales --lower prior year retail sales. Market share in EMEA was up 0.3% [indiscernible] basis.  Asia Pacific retail sales growth slowed as we very strong retail sales comps of up nearly 17%.  And as we temporarily exited the market in Indonesia earlier this year in order to establish a dealer network and a new dealer network and improve customer experience. Latin America retail sales trends improved significantly from last quarter behind continued strong growth in Mexico. Weakness in Brazil drove overall sales declines in the region as the sales continue to be impacted by challenging economic and consumer uncertainty. In response to the nearly 50% devaluation of the Brazilian real last year, we raised model year 2016 prices over 20% to improve profitability per motorcycle. We continue to expect retail sales to be down for the year. Finally, retail sales in Canada were up 2.0% in the second quarter. We believe the market continued to respond well to the change to a direct distribution model and pricing adjustments that were made at the model year.
[indiscernible] of our strategic focus on increasing brand access, we plan to continue to expand our international distribution. We added 6 new international dealerships in the second quarter. On Slide 13, you'll see wholesale shipments of Harley-Davidson Motorcycles in the quarter were slightly above our guidance as we shipped ahead of the Q3 ERP implementation. As a result, U.S. shipments and retail inventory increased during the quarter and company inventory fell below prior year levels. Our production plants were idled earlier this month and overall production was down above 30% in July as we successfully implemented our ERP system in Kansas City. We began model year '17 production on schedule.
Second quarter shipment mix reflected strong demand for our new 2016 Cruiser and Sportster Motorcycles. On Slide 14, you'll see revenue for the Motorcycles and product segment was up in the second quarter behind a 3.5% increase in Motorcycles shipment. Revenue in the quarter was unfavorably impacted [indiscernible] significant shift in mix to our Cruiser and Sportster Motorcycles and slightly unfavorable currency exchange, partially offset by higher pricing. As a result, average motorcycle revenue per unit was down for the quarter.
On Slide 15 you'll see gross margin as a percentage of revenue in the quarter was down to 2.8 percentage points versus last year.  While we expected Q2 gross margin to be unfavorable driven by mix currency and manufacturing, the impacts from mix and manufacturing were more unfavorable than we anticipated. During the quarter, customer demand for our Cruisers and Sportsters exceeded expectations, which led to higher-than-expected mix unfavorability of $17.6 million. As we expected, foreign currency exchange was negative as we lapped significant hedge gains in last year's second quarter, and as we have lower revenues behind a strategy stronger U.S. dollar.
Manufacturing expenses were higher-than-expected, unfavorable $36.1 million during the second quarter. We did expect significant unfavorable variances largely driven by startup cost related to the implementation of our ERP system in Kansas City, and cost associated with significant plant retooling. However, as Matt explained, plant efficiencies over lower-than-expected due to lower production given soft sales in Q2, and other plant disruptions. It is important to note, the increase in manufacturing costs that we've experienced in this first half of this year are largely temporary in nature and we would not expect the majority of these costs to recur in 2017.  Looking forward, we continue to expect Q3 manufacturing expense to be unfavorable behind lower absorption and higher year-over-year startup cost. Conversely, we expect manufacturing favorability in Q4.
On Slide 16, operating margin as a percent of revenue for the second quarter was 19.3%, down compared to last year's second quarter. Operating margin was unfavorably impacted by lower gross margin as well as [indiscernible] SG&A resulting from both our increased investments in driving demand and product development and from costs associated with managing our Canadian operations, which we acquired in August of 2015. For the full year, we expect SG&A to be year-ago levels.
We remain intensely focused on our cost structure that will enable growth and continuous improvement to drive our business to be stronger, more flexible and more profitable.
Moving on to HDFS on Slide 16, during the quarter HDFS's operating profit increased $7.7 million or 9.4% compared to last year. The primary factors impacting second quarter results were: First, net interest income was up over the year by $5.0 million. This increase was driven by higher receivables, partially offset by higher borrowing cost and lower yields, due in part to the 2015 lower interest rate promotional activity. Second, the provision for retail motorcycle loan losses increased over prior year by $8.2 million driven by higher retail credit losses and an associated increase in the allowance. It is important to note that second quarter provision increase was significantly less than what we experienced in the first quarter of 2016. Finally, you will see, on the slide a gain on full securitization. This represents a full securitization in which we sold retail finance receivables with a balance of approximately $302 million, along with all the residual financial interest in those receivables. Because we have no order ship interest in the receivables, the transaction was recorded as a sale, which in this case resulted in a gain of $9.3 million.
HDFS's operational results are summarized on Slide 18. For the quarter, originations were down 3.9% compared to last year, but HDFS's share of U.S  new retail motorcycle loans -- motorcycle sales increased to 63.4%. Year-to-date loan originations were comprised of approximately 80% prime loans and subprime.  As a predominant industry leader to subprime customers, these originations continue to represent a significant number of retail sales to the company at very attractive returns. At the end of the second quarter, we had $419 million of cash and cash equivalents at HDFS. In addition, HDFS had $1.02 billion of available liquidity through bank credit and conduit facilities. HDFS also paid a $43 million dividend to HD Inc. during the quarter, which would I will talk more about in the moment. On Slide 19, you'll see the 30-day delinquency rate for retail motorcycle loan receivables that remained on our balance sheet was 3.16%, or 45 basis points higher than Q2 2015. 14 basis points of the increase represents a change in the mix of the portfolio after the securitization of $302 million [indiscernible] prime receivables. The delinquency rate on a managed basis, including those rules sold in full securitization was still 31 basis points higher than the prior year due in part to deterioration in oil-dependent areas. Despite the increase, delinquencies remain near historically low levels.
Annualized retail credit losses for receivables that remain on our balance sheet was 1.50% or 42 basis points higher than Q2 2015. On a managed basis, the credit loss rate was 1.49%. The increase was a result of higher losses on loans in oil-dependent areas, normalizing loan performance and lower used bike values at auction. During the quarter, HDFS continues to maintain a strong liquidity position and continued strong profitability to the company. The remaining Harley-Davidson Inc. financial results are summarized on Slide 20. A few things to note. Operating cash was down from last year driven by [indiscernible] income, higher working capital, and higher net wholesale lending. And year-to-date tax rate was 32.7%, which was lower than last year's tax rate behind the successful closure of various tax audits allowing us to reduce our tax reserves. The company has and intends to continue to maintain a minimum of 12 months of projected liquidity needs in cash and/or committed credit facilities. Returning value to our shareholders is a top priority. We expect to return all excess cash to our shareholders in the form of increasing dividends and continued share repurchases. On Slide 21, you will see we did both, during the second quarter. In addition, as I mentioned earlier, during the quarter we completed a full securitization, because we sold all ownership interest in the receivables. The receivables and any corresponding that are not recorded on HDFS's balance sheet. Consequently, this allowed HDFS to pay a dividend of HD Inc. of [indiscernible] without impacting HDFS's debt-to-equity ratio. We used the dividend to repurchase shares under the existing share repurchase authorizations.  While we believe the EPS impact was neutral, the shareholder repurchase associated with the full securitization increased our shareholders' ownership in the company at a time when our stock is trading at historically low PE. This was a first-time HDFS or we believe any other manufacturer has utilized this market. Actions such as this demonstrate our commitment to explore avenues to improve funding costs, diversify funding sources and return excess cash to our shareholders. We'll continue to look for additional opportunities to return excess cash to our shareholders without damaging our long-term value of the company or the brand. On Slide 22, you'll see our overall expectations for 2016. We now expect to ship 264,000 to 269,000 Motorcycles, which is approximately down 1% to up 1% over last year. We expect third quarter shipments to be approximately flat to down 9% versus last year's third quarter. For the full year, 2016, we now expect operating margin for the Motorcycles segment to be approximately 15% to 16%. We're lowering our expectations by approximately 1 percentage point due to lost absorption on lower production, unfavorable mix and higher manufacturing expense. Finally, we now expect a full year 2016 effective tax rate will be approximately 33%. Our 2016 directional expectations for gross margin, SG&A, HDFS and capital expenditures are unchanged and noted on the slide.
While the weak U.S. industry and continued intense competition grow less than expected sales during the quarter, we're encouraged by the positive market share results from our demand driving investments and new models. We're also pleased to see international retail sales grow despite macroeconomic headwinds. We continue to [indiscernible] decisions to support a prudent retail inventory position and to protect our strong brand and profitability into the future. We're maintaining our intense focus on maximizing shareholder value by returning cash to our shareholders through share repurchases and increased dividends. We'll continue to navigate through the challenging environment and are making investments to drive demand and deliver stronger -- and deliver strong margins and strong returns over the long term.
Now, let's take your questions.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Baird.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, with respect to industry demand, what do think accounts for the significant weakness in new bikes sales? Specifically, what role did either credit conditions, or surplus in the supply of used bikes account for some of that weakness in new demand?
componenttext: Matt, with respect to industry demand, what do think accounts for the significant weakness in new bikes sales? Specifically, what role did either credit conditions, or surplus in the supply of used bikes account for some of that weakness in new demand?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Craig. I actually think that there is a lot going on. So it's really difficult to lay it on any specific thing. Certainly the uncertainty in the political environment, credit conditions as you mentioned, the oil-dependent regions that we discussed
componenttext: Thanks, Craig. I actually think that there is a lot going on. So it's really difficult to lay it on any specific thing. Certainly the uncertainty in the political environment, credit conditions as you mentioned, the oil-dependent regions that we discussed, we have sort of numbers associated with that in particular. Also the significant growth last year, as I mentioned, in the corresponding comp for this year, we knew that, that was going to create pressure. The forecast for the industry growth was kind of in that  2% range and clearly it's not materializing that way.  And so we're looking at it very carefully, investing in new products and awareness and rider training and focusing our efforts what we can do to not only grow share, but grow our sales [indiscernible] and primarily doing that through growing the sport. So there is a lot real positive things in that realm. I mentioned, some of them in my opening remarks. But clearly this is a disappointment and we're regrouping as a result of it and doubling down on what we know is working to drive the industry.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I had a question on the SG&A. I know you flattish year-over-year, but it was up nicely in the first half of the year. So, where are you going to see the opportunities to have those dollars decline in the back half. And then when you look out in futu
componenttext: John, I had a question on the SG&A. I know you flattish year-over-year, but it was up nicely in the first half of the year. So, where are you going to see the opportunities to have those dollars decline in the back half. And then when you look out in future years, is there more room to kind of keep that SG&A flattish in the future years, or how you guys thinking about that?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sharon. So as you pointed out, when we look at SG&A over the first half, it is up about 6%. And I'm looking at a full year guidance to be flat to up slightly. Obviously the back half is going to be down. We would expect the third quarter to still
componenttext: Thanks, Sharon. So as you pointed out, when we look at SG&A over the first half, it is up about 6%. And I'm looking at a full year guidance to be flat to up slightly. Obviously the back half is going to be down. We would expect the third quarter to still be up on a year-over-year basis as we continue to spend that incremental investment in driving demand. And then we would expect the fourth quarter to be down quite a bit in terms of SG&A. And remember Sharon that in the fourth quarter of last year, there was a restructuring charge in that number of about $23 million in SG&A. And so, with that, as long as the other reductions that we've made in the core infrastructure of the company to fund the incremental demand driving investments, we would expect the overall back half of the year to be down in SG&A. In terms of going forward -- sorry in terms of going forward, we're focused on managing SG&A, but continuing to invest in the future, whether that be new products or certainly the marketing of those.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix of Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix of Barclays.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, this question is for you both Matt and John. Do you think that you are positioned appropriately for the declining industry that seemed to surprise you in the quarter. I'm just wondering if your plans for the second half and also for next year are
componenttext: I guess, this question is for you both Matt and John. Do you think that you are positioned appropriately for the declining industry that seemed to surprise you in the quarter. I'm just wondering if your plans for the second half and also for next year are appropriate for the current environment. I mean, I understand the reasons behind the inventory bill that you talked about, positioned for the new models, getting ahead of Kansas City ERP. But just given the environment, given the surprises that continued to comment and given the competition, I'm just wondering how much you have stress tested your growth plans for the second half and for next year?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks Felicia. Let me break the question up into 2 answers. First, inventory as we exit the first half. Retail inventory was up 20 -- I'm sorry 8300 [indiscernible] largely driven by 5 incremental models. On average our dealers have about 2 1/2 of
componenttext: Okay, thanks Felicia. Let me break the question up into 2 answers. First, inventory as we exit the first half. Retail inventory was up 20 -- I'm sorry 8300 [indiscernible] largely driven by 5 incremental models. On average our dealers have about 2 1/2 of each of those models in their dealerships and that adds up actually to over 8,000 units, but we also wanted to ship in ahead of the ERP implementation. And so when we look at second quarter and you also -- you look at the retail side, which is up 8,300 units, our company-owned inventory is down quite a bit and when you net those 2, we're basically up in the second quarter, 1/3 of July's production and that's what we expect to lose. So to answer your question, as we exit the first half, we're right in line with what we expected in terms of inventory on a year-over-year basis, again to compensate for the lost production in July. When we extend that forward, we were expecting inventories and the U.S. to grow behind additional models and given that environment that you have mentioned, and certainly that we experienced in the second quarter, we're more cautious and want to be more prudent from an inventory perspective. And with that we do not expect inventories to grow [indiscernible] United States at year-end. And yes, we absolutely feel that is the appropriate level of inventory given the soft retail that we are seeing in the first half of this year.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question John. I'll just add my perspective on it. My short answer is, yes. I think we've looked very clear-eyed with the condition in the industry year-to-date, projected that forward and what you see in John's comments finishing flat with
componenttext: That's a great question John. I'll just add my perspective on it. My short answer is, yes. I think we've looked very clear-eyed with the condition in the industry year-to-date, projected that forward and what you see in John's comments finishing flat with additional models is actually leaning out our inventory and you can read from that, that we expect and we believe is embedded in our numbers, the industry to continue to be soft for the balance of the year and probably into next year as well. And so we are adequately provisioning and preparing for that. But, and I guess, also with a healthy dose of realism, given what we saw that was quite surprising here in the second quarter. So, we feel like we're in very good shape on both sales and inventory for the balance of the year as well as heading into next year of the level.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, on HDFS, with the prime sale, how do you see any of those potential transactions going forward and then does this leave you with more loans that you still have on the balance sheet or exposure to a higher mix of prime? And then one other things rela
componenttext: John, on HDFS, with the prime sale, how do you see any of those potential transactions going forward and then does this leave you with more loans that you still have on the balance sheet or exposure to a higher mix of prime? And then one other things related to Brexit, what have you seen in the U.K. and U.S. retail trends post the Brexit vote? Any impact whatsoever?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. When we look at the securitization that we recently did about a month ago, there were 2 changes in that securitization from normal securitizations that we execute. [indiscernible] pointed out is that they were made up of 100% of prime receiva
componenttext: Thanks, Tim. When we look at the securitization that we recently did about a month ago, there were 2 changes in that securitization from normal securitizations that we execute. [indiscernible] pointed out is that they were made up of 100% of prime receivables. And the second one is we sold the residual interest that allowed us to classify it off the balance sheet. Your question centers around the prime aspect of it.  So historically, we have sold securitization that resemble our originations, about 80% prime and 20% subprime. And for all kinds of speculation as to why we did 100% prime, so let me clear that up. Some of that speculation has been as we can't sel subprime into the market and that is absolute untruth nonsense. So for over a decade we've been selling a mix of prime and subprime into very robust demand in the marketplace and that has not changed at all. What has changed over the last couple of securitization is that our spreads have widened on the securitization to our benchmark. Our benchmark is prime model and there is no one else that does a mixture of securitizations like we do. So we benchmark the prime model. What we have noticed over the last couple securitizations [indiscernible] it widening out a little bit. And so the best way to tether them back was to get a comparable securitization to our benchmark. And with that, we saw extreme tightening of those margins or of those spreads to prime model. So we as we look forward whether we decide to do all-prime or subprime, in-prime, kind of the tethering of the investment community to that spread against prime has been very important us and will pay dividends as we move into the future. So that's why we move forward with the prime securitization. Your second question is with regards to Brexit.  At this point, there is not enough information and not enough time has gone back to understand the impact of Brexit. And I think what we're's very certain of is that Brexit does not provide any benefit retail sales or consumer confidence in Europe. And I think this is what Matt talked about a little [indiscernible] I will put it into a broader bucket instead of just Brexit as overall consumer confidence driven by geopolitical concerns or macroeconomic concerns.  But very excited about the momentum that we have in our European business.  As you can see for the quarter, it was up quite significantly.  We'll keep a close eye on Brexit, but we're going to focus on what we can control and continue to drive a great customer experience for our customers around the world.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian of Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian of Citigroup.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: To questions. First on Tim's question, just Europe, 8% growth this quarter. What was the key driver for the?  And how sustainable can it be, because it's been -- it was strong last quarter as well, pretty similar. And then second, there was some speculation that I think you are in discussions or maybe received an offer from private equity firm few weeks back, just wondering is that the case or are you -- were  you in any serious conversations or are you at this point?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. First question Greg is with regards to Europe, again we couldn't be more pleased.  Again, Matt mentioned  it in his upfront remarks is the focus of our European team and getting people on our Motorcycles.  The demos that they are doing has give
componenttext: All right. First question Greg is with regards to Europe, again we couldn't be more pleased.  Again, Matt mentioned  it in his upfront remarks is the focus of our European team and getting people on our Motorcycles.  The demos that they are doing has given a tremendous amount of volume in that market. Also our product offering, you got to remember that Europe has got a better mix of cruisers than we have in The United States. The product is just as well received in Europe as it is here in The United States.  That certainly is helping to drive some of the performance. And we expect the team there to continue to focus on getting people exposed to our Motorcycles and we cannot again be more pleased with where we're at and growing market share, again in just as a competitive market and The United States, not driven by price [indiscernible] Europe, by tremendous addition of a lower displacement Motorcycles and again we're doing well and gaining share in a robustly growing market in Europe. The second comment is with regards to market rumors surrounding our stock and a potential private equity investor, we don't comment on any rumors -- any stock market rumors. That would consume our entire life if we did that.

componenttextpreview: A clarification in the question from me. I guess, first, obviously, retail was materially worse than what you anticipated and yet the shipments were actually a little bit higher than the high end of guidance. I guess what was different there than how you
componenttext: A clarification in the question from me. I guess, first, obviously, retail was materially worse than what you anticipated and yet the shipments were actually a little bit higher than the high end of guidance. I guess what was different there than how you anticipated heading into the quarter? And then maybe a little bit of follow up to Robin's question. We're trending towards the lower end of that down 1 to up 1 2 in terms of retail year-to-date. I guess what gives you confidence that the industry and/or your numbers will get any better. I guess, what happens if the industry gets worse [indiscernible] most recent data point is a stepdown from what we saw in the first quarter?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, James. When you look at the second quarter, I mean, we did ship a little bit over the high end of guidance and at the same time, during the quarter, we've been cutting production quite dramatically and our retail sales were down. So you're s
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, James. When you look at the second quarter, I mean, we did ship a little bit over the high end of guidance and at the same time, during the quarter, we've been cutting production quite dramatically and our retail sales were down. So you're saying is "Can you help me out,  help me understand this."  So basically, as we got to the end of the quarter, we had all the product made and that was either in retail or in our company-owned inventory and typically we have a bit of company-owned inventory in United States that facilitates the flow and the orderly shipments of Motorcycles. We made the decision to ship It all out prior to the period, The reason we did that is in the very outside chance that we had any issues with the ERP system. If they are in our system, we may have trouble getting them shipped. So it was just a simple de-risking of the overall ERP implementation. I couldn't be more pleased to say that the team did a fantastic job.  Everything came up as expected.  The ramp plans are on plan and everything is moving forward. But, James, it was simply that.  That is, we can take a little bit more risk out of it. Now having said that, overall inventory as I mentioned, I think to Felicia, overall inventories didn't change, but we had company owned inventories on lower on the year-over-year basis and we put a little bit more into the field. So, overall inventories are where we would have expected them despite the lower unexpected sales based on our production reductions and lower company-owned inventory. The second question that you asked is with regards to our revised guidance, which is down 1 to up 1.  We go through a robust process looking at all factors, and I think that we know in the marketplace, which is centered around new dealerships coming up in the international markets, we will have more dealers in the back half, new dealers in the back half than the front half. We look at the performance of Outreach in The United States. That's performing extremely well. We look at the investments that we've made. I mean the demand driving activities what we expect to come out of those. And certainly and most importantly we look at the new models that we're going to be launching here and 3 to 4 weeks and we couldn't be more excited about that. You take all those together, James, we're very confident that we're going to ship from 264,000 to 269,000 Motorcycles for 2016.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Katz from MorningStar.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Katz from MorningStar.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, I'm curious with regards to inventory and what's in the channel now in light of the slower growth environment. Can you just talk about your thoughts on the ability to take prices. In the next model you're coming online? And then if you would commen
componenttext: First, I'm curious with regards to inventory and what's in the channel now in light of the slower growth environment. Can you just talk about your thoughts on the ability to take prices. In the next model you're coming online? And then if you would comment on where you might be seeing the most share gains. I think the share losses last year were from internationally competitors, but it sounds like that is still a decent amount of discounting going on.  So if you have color on that, that would be really helpful.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. With regards to inventory, retail sales, we talked a little bit about that. We feel that we're at the right spot, given our forward look at retail sales, given where we expect inventories to be. And  if we haven't shown our resolve to manage this com
componenttext: Yes. With regards to inventory, retail sales, we talked a little bit about that. We feel that we're at the right spot, given our forward look at retail sales, given where we expect inventories to be. And  if we haven't shown our resolve to manage this company for the long-term value of our shareholders in the actions that we've taken to keep in the marketplace or aggressively manage supply in line with demand, we're not going to discount our way out of this soft spot that we're expecting. The people are looking. We have got tremendous results and we'll manage the inventory at appropriate levels. And now with regards to pricing, I'm not going to speak a lot of that because in 3 weeks you will see the new models and you will see the pricing and you can answer that question for yourself, Jamie. But again, we feel very comfortable where we're at with regards to the market and we will continue to manage it very tightly. I'm glad you asked about share gains in United States. I couldn't be more thrilled to answer this question. A year ago, we sat here, Matt and I, Matt's first conference call and we said that we had an issue given the shift in world currencies and the incredible competitiveness that came out of that, in particular in discounting. And we said that we were not going to discount our way out of it. We weren't going to drain the industry of profits and chase this thing. And it was going to take us some time, but we were going to spend more time understanding what we need to do and how we can compete in the world of expanded price gaps without cheapening our brand And now, dial forward a couple of quarters, we're there and we delivered 2 points of market share gains. So, let me talk second about those.  The gains were very strong and wide. Number 1, that came in all of our segments, our Touring segments, our Cruisers and our Street Sportster segment size of our Motorcycles. They came in the 7 sales regions that we have in The United States. We gained share in each and every one of them. Our gains were over double than nearest competitor. When you look broadly at those share gains, what we saw is the biggest loser, were in aggregate Japanese competitors. We also saw, while we mentioned in the preamble, that the overall discounting was higher on a year-over-year basis. We did see the Japanese discounting be down a little bit versus a year ago, and it seems to be reflecting in their market share. With that we saw rotation in the brand discounting from the Japanese to the American brands in the second quarter and we're seeing some of the share gains in there. Overall, Europeans market share was down a little bit, but we had some big vendors and big losers in the segment. Hopefully that helps, Jamie.

componenttext: I realize what you want to say '17 just given we are so close to the roll-out.  But I guess what I wanted to ask is what did you learn from all your '16 products and the way it was received in a more competitive environment that guided you on your plans for '17?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. I appreciate the question.  Actually we're incredibly pleased with the model year '16 products and how they drove the market globally. This is a lot of S models that we launched a year ago, basically, as well as a products we introduced dur
componenttext: Thanks, David. I appreciate the question.  Actually we're incredibly pleased with the model year '16 products and how they drove the market globally. This is a lot of S models that we launched a year ago, basically, as well as a products we introduced during the model year. And clearly, there's a lot of constraints in this competitive environment that we're in, but our product drives customer passion, customer loyalty and sales and market share. We saw that with the shift in sales to large Cruisers, which helped us gain share.  Those large Cruisers and a little lower margin than our Motorcycles, so that's part of our gross margin deterioration that we just spoke about on the call today.  But product is a very key lever for us.  One of our 4 focus areas to increase about the cadence and the impact of the product and 2016 Is a good example of both. High-impact product at an increase cadence. And 2017 is going to be no different. It is a formula that is working for us and we have invested more heavily both capital and expense as part of the demand driving shift to make sure that the product that we deliver makes a difference in the marketplace and that we do it well and we do it more rapidly. And so that's a new pattern for us that we can expect rolling forward in 2017, 2018 and beyond.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of follow-ups here. So the gain on sale on HDFS, I guess, help us understand -- I'm assuming that, that gain comes out of future potential and come that we would have otherwise seen in a normal securitization transaction. How should we think about
componenttext: Couple of follow-ups here. So the gain on sale on HDFS, I guess, help us understand -- I'm assuming that, that gain comes out of future potential and come that we would have otherwise seen in a normal securitization transaction. How should we think about that?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, James. It's a good question. In the 8-K that we put out, we talked about this overall transaction is neutral when you look at the present value of earnings per share. So it's a great question. Basically, here is what happens is, in a securitizatio
componenttext: Thanks, James. It's a good question. In the 8-K that we put out, we talked about this overall transaction is neutral when you look at the present value of earnings per share. So it's a great question. Basically, here is what happens is, in a securitization we sell off of a bunch of bonds to investors. And there is a -- it goes into our trust and all the residual earnings that we get off that, we keep, because -- we keep the risk and we keep that reward. What we [indiscernible] slightly different market and we found an investor to buy that. And what they did is they paid us a bunch of upfront cash to buy that residual interest in the trust or those trailing earnings. We believe that the opportunity cost of the transaction that we did is about $7 million of those trailing earnings. So to do broad math we took a $9 million, gave up about $7 million of opportunity cost. So they would have earned about $16 million. We took $9 million today right. So if you take any discount over the next 7 years that $7 million that would have come in, bring it to the present value and that impact on EPS along with the fact that because it's off balance sheet, we freed up equity at HDFS to maintain the same debt-to-equity, we've now got more equity.  So HDFS wrote a check that works out to be $43 million and we bought shares back with that. And if you take that impact on EPS, they were about neutral. So, the question is why did we do it if it's a neutral? #1 is once you get in the market you don't know how the market is going to exactly respond, but there's 2 reasons that we did this. #1 is this additional source of liquidity. So we're always looking for opportunities, more investors, more liquidity and this is a great opportunity. The other thing, with the additional liquidity opportunity, we also learned that we can monetize the assets on our balance sheet to some extent. And that is very important to know. So that's #1 reason. Number 2 and the more important reason is, is one of our -- we talked about it at every conference call, a top priority of ours is to return value to our shareholders in the form of rising dividends and share repurchases and we would look at every opportunity to do that with the caveat that we're not going to do anything to damage the long-term value of the brand of the company. This transaction fits squarely in there. There is absolutely no extra [indiscernible] in the company or anything like that. What it did is it liberated $43 million of excess cash. That excess cash was used to buy share repurchases. And even though, again, from a present value basis, we're neutral line EPS, we believe that our long-term shareholders would prefer to have at this moment in time, more equity in our company given historically low PEs that we are trading at. And so they get the ownership today versus waiting over that period of time for the opportunity cost of that money.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: That's really helpful. And maybe just 2 really quick hitters here. Inventory is going to be down domestically, are the also going to be -- I'm sorry flat domestically. Are they also going to be flat internationally or will we see some growth there. And you also mentioned I think earlier in the Q&A that you maybe had some stats on oil areas versus non-oil areas. I was wondering if you care to share those.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, James.  Internationally we expect to grow a modestly as well.  We will be adding a lot of dealerships [indiscernible] year and they're growing markets and we would expect to add a little bit of inventory internationally. The second quarter -- your s
componenttext: Sure, James.  Internationally we expect to grow a modestly as well.  We will be adding a lot of dealerships [indiscernible] year and they're growing markets and we would expect to add a little bit of inventory internationally. The second quarter -- your second question is on oil-dependent areas. We going to talk about this last quarter.  It is certainly a headwind to the industry. And what we saw about a year ago, first quarter 2015, we first noticed that those areas were declining more than other areas in the United States, obviously driven by the depression in the oil prices. We saw that increase from a modest amount in the first quarter, increased in the second and third quarter and it hit about 10% rate in the fourth quarter. Now we have seen that hold to 10% in the fourth quarter of last year, the first quarter of this year and the second quarter was also a 10. As we look forward, we're going to start to lap more significant rises on a year-over-year basis . hopefully we'll start to see it temper a little bit, but at this point, it is not getting worse, but it is not getting better either.

componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the demand creation money that you are spending.  Is $70 million still a good number for this year? When did you kind of start to deploy that? Where are you seeing some of the best traction and then would you consider spend
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the demand creation money that you are spending.  Is $70 million still a good number for this year? When did you kind of start to deploy that? Where are you seeing some of the best traction and then would you consider spending more or even less as you kind of look forward?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scot. Great question. So again, going back to a year ago, we tried some things in the second and third quarter. Some worked, some didn't. We kind of regrouped. Looked at what was working, what wasn't  and we sized the overall opportunity. We came
componenttext: Thanks, Scot. Great question. So again, going back to a year ago, we tried some things in the second and third quarter. Some worked, some didn't. We kind of regrouped. Looked at what was working, what wasn't  and we sized the overall opportunity. We came back as a company and said we needed $70 million to really address the widened price caps, which is a headwind to us in and compete without lowering price or discounting. And then we got into the marketplace early in this first quarter, $70 million and again we're very pleased with what we're seeing in terms of new people coming into, being trained through our Rider Academy, the Motorcycles that they are buying with that, the demos that are going on, Live Your Legend campaign, the Heroes Ride Free that promotions that we're getting, people that identify very closely with our brand, getting them fee training to get on Motorcycles.  All of that is working well and you're seeing that manifest itself in our competitiveness with expanded price gaps in the second quarter. In terms of where we go with the $70 million. That's something that we evaluate an ongoing basis. And not only the overall dollar amount of the $70 million, we'll look at and change if need to be whether that be more or less. We're also looking at what's working and what's not. And trying to become very nimble on how we redirect the money in the right spots, whether that be with a market or between markets, within a promotion or between promotions. [indiscernible] there's nothing, but single-minded focus here in driving demand.
